thought.translation[0].definitions[0].de: the past tense and past participle of think1
thought.translation[1].definitions[0].de: something that you think of, remember, or realize
thought.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: The thought that I might not have a job next year is a bit troubling.
thought.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: With more thought and care this would have been a first-class essay.
I’ve been giving your proposal a lot of thought.
give something thought/give thought to something
Have you given any more thought to going back to school?
give something thought/give thought to something
thought.translation[1].definitions[2].de: the act or process of thinking
thought.translation[1].definitions[2].ex: Piaget’s research focused on children’s thought processes (=the way their minds work).
Derek was staring out of the window, lost in thought.
thought.translation[1].definitions[3].de: a feeling of worrying or caring about something
thought.translation[1].definitions[3].ex: You are always in my thoughts (=used to tell someone that you think and care about them a lot).
He went back into the burning building with no thought for his own safety.
Have you no thought for anyone but yourself?
thought.translation[1].definitions[4].de: intention or hope of doing something
thought.translation[1].definitions[4].ex: I had no thought of gaining any personal advantage.
Lucy gave up all thought of finishing the essay that day.
thought.translation[1].definitions[5].de: a way of thinking that is typical of a particular group, period of history etc
thought.translation[1].definitions[5].ex: Kant’s ideas had a strong influence on political thought.
thought.translation[1].note_box[0].secti: have a thought
I just had a funny thought.
express your thoughts
He was finding it difficult to express his thoughts.
a thought occurs to/comes to/strikes somebody
The thought occurred to him that she might be lying.
a thought crosses somebody’s mind
The thought never crossed my mind that I could be wrong.
can’t bear the thought of something
I can’t bear the thought of you being hurt.
somebody’s thoughts turn to something
As summer approaches, people’s thoughts turn to holidays.
somebody’s first thought
My first thought was that a bomb had gone off.
a passing thought
He never gives his appearance more than a passing thought.
a sobering thought
We have the power to destroy the world, which is a sobering thought.
horrible/disturbing
A horrible thought struck her: could he be having an affair?
a comforting thought
‘People might not have noticed we’re late.’ ‘That’s a comforting thought.’
a sudden thought
A sudden thought struck her and she began to laugh.
the very thought
The very thought of going on stage made her feel ill.
